text: It feels like you’re throwing away a lot of very useful data if you do it the second way, would be very surprised if it worked! Never done it that way but would be interested to hear if anyones had any success with it
The problem with the first approach it is that the probability sum is always more than 1, which seems inaccurate to me.

text: The sum is not 1.
You mean probabilities implied from each runner SP ?

text: No. Based on a model who gives each horse a rating.

text:
Two things to try would be:
• normalize your probabilities - divide each probability by the sum of all of them
• use a multiclass classifier instead of binary (which im guessing is what you’re currently doing)

elements.text: Two things to try would be:
normalize your probabilities - divide each probability by the sum of all of them
use a multiclass classifier instead of binary (which im guessing is what you’re currently doing)

text: <@U02GGCCLTKM> normalized probabilities are very similar, so I think it's not a good predictor.

text: Looks like a pretty plausible market shape to me!

But the deviation from the odds at that moment was pretty high.

Ex: the favorite odd from the predict probability (0.1483) is ~6.74, but on the market it was something like 2.8

text: The thing with (B)SP is that although its a benchmark at scale, the accuracy of individual SPs is unknowable and at best a range.

elements.text: The thing with (B)SP is that although its a benchmark at scale, the accuracy of individual SPs is unknowable and at best a range.

text: I find it really difficult to get results that are consistently close to the market prices. I try not to worry too much about that, and focus on what the P&L would be over a long period of time

text: So you dont care at BSP at all ?

text: Oh I definitely do :joy: I should have said - P&L and BSP over a long period

Hey all, I've been working on and off with price only indicators for awhile. For short term price changes, my predictions are not too bad, but i'm finding it hard to get matched at predictions to make any decent money (even in back-testing).

So I'm looking to change strategy to a value based approach. I'm wondering if any of you have a suggestion of where to gather runner (or team) data, and a ball-park estimation of how much the data costs to have enough for predicting successful value? I'm currently doing a Machine Learning PhD and hoping to see how well I can apply it, but this does mean I'm on somewhat of a budget!

Thank you!

elements.text:

I'm currently doing a Machine Learning PhD and hoping to see how well I can apply it, but this does mean I'm on somewhat of a budget!

text:
My predictions of price movement is only accurate for a short period of time. I've found I can rarely get matched on the correct side before the price moves.

I've been working with UK horse-racing and filtering by a over a certain matched to ensure fluidity.

I'd take any to be honest, it's all just data to me - as long as it's descriptive enough to predict value. I took a look at Total performance data but couldn't find any prices or many reviews if this service was worth it.

text: Any strategy that makes money needs to get value so you are heading in the right direction. Your question is very open but many (including myself) are profitable working purely off market data and many others are profitable off free form data, you don't have to spend money to find an edge

Interesting, thanks for the reply. I've been mainly focused on taking small profits from selection greening back/lay over short periods of time. What do you count as value? Is just value on BSP?

So my objective would be to model the current state of the market and predict an accurate BSP, and then I can make value decisions based on this prediction, instead of short term price movements?

elements.text:
Interesting, thanks for the reply. I've been mainly focused on taking small profits from selection greening back/lay over short periods of time. What do you count as value? Is just value on BSP?

So my objective would be to model the current state of the market and predict an accurate BSP, and then I can make value decisions based on this prediction, instead of short term price movements?

text: Take a step back, you can't make money without getting value.
BSP is a good gauge (not perfect) on the true value so if you can beat BSP you likely have value
#nevergreen
